item.title: Will I Have to Download a New TikTok App? And Other Big Questions About The Deal.
item.description: The popular short form video app has a new corporate structure in the United States, which could result in some changes for the 200 million Americans who use TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: It is unclear how much, if anything, will change for TikTok’s 200 million American users.

item.title: Here’s Who Just Bought TikTok
item.description: Several big companies and investment firms are part of the new American TikTok. Many have ties to one another and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times

item.title: Big Insurers Try to Shift Blame for High Health Costs to Hospitals and Drug Makers
item.description: At two congressional hearings, lawmakers slammed executives of major companies, saying they were failing to rein in the cost of medical care for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assn
item.media:description: Stephen Hemsley, chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, left, defended insurers’ practices, along with other companies’ executives, during congressional hearings on Thursday.

item.title: New U.S. Rule Aims to Speed Up Mining of the Seafloor
item.description: The Metals Company, a prominent seabed-mining company, applauded the change and filed a new application more than doubling the area it hopes to mine.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company to explore the viability of mining the seabed in the Pacific in 2021.

item.title: Trump Could Begin Flying on Plane Donated by Qatar by Summer
item.description: It remains unclear whether the aircraft would get the full Air Force One security upgrades, which industry experts said could take up to two years to complete.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Trump had to swap to a smaller plane used as Air Force One on Tuesday night, as he was heading to Switzerland, after an electrical issue with the larger aircraft.

item.title: Trump Sues JPMorgan, Saying the Bank Closed His Accounts for Political Reasons
item.description: The lawsuit, citing “political discrimination,” said the banking giant told President Trump shortly after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol that it would close his accounts.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: The lawsuit says Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan’s chief executive, directed the bank to put Mr. Trump and some of his businesses on a “blacklist.”

item.title: How a Major Winter Storm This Weekend Could Affect Your Travel Plans
item.description: Ice, sleet and possibly significant snowfall are threatening to snarl travel in much of the eastern U.S. starting on Friday. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: Ronald Reagan National Airport, near Washington, is one of dozens of airports that could experience delays this weekend.

item.title: Why Trump’s Reversal on Greenland Still Leaves Europe on Edge
item.description: Andrew Ross Sorkin, editor at large of DealBook, describes how leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos remain on edge after President Trump, for now, backed down from threats of using tariffs or military force to gain Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Rebecca Suner, Coleman Lowndes and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Betting on Prediction Markets Is Their Job. They Make Millions.
item.description: Welcome to the era of the Polymarket sharp.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Wallace
item.media:credit: Oliver Farshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joel Holsinger made hundreds of dollars on Kalshi after correctly guessing which turkey President Trump would pardon last year.

item.title: Consumer Prices Rose 2.8 Percent Through November 2025, a Sign of Sticky Inflation
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred gauge for inflation in October and November was released belatedly after the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:description: Goods inflation, which had been notably cooling since 2022, swung back up after the Trump administration implemented tariffs last spring

item.title: Trump Returns to a Familiar Role: Sowing Trade Chaos
item.description: The president’s quick reversal on tariffs over Greenland was another sign of his willingness to rip up the international order — even parts of it that he himself has made.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Trump on Wednesday gave a menacing speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, before backtracking on a brewing trade war with Europe.

item.title: Trump and ‘Taco!’ Roil Davos
item.description: Business leaders at the World Economic Forum were relieved by the president’s about-face on Greenland, but remain on edge about what could come next.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Lauren Hirsch and Ian Mount
item.media:description: President Trump’s appearance at the World Economic Forum was greeted with relief and anxiety by business and political leaders.

item.title: The Leverage That Europe Has Over the U.S. Economy
item.description: After the latest bout of trade turmoil with the United States, European leaders are looking for ways to project strength to the Trump administration, which considers them weak.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, said in a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that the E.U. response to U.S. aggression would be “unflinching, united and proportional.”

item.title: Oscar Nominations: ‘Sinners’ Breaks Record With 16
item.description: “One Battle After Another” was close behind with 13 nods. Acting nominees include Michael B. Jordan, Kate Hudson, Timothée Chalamet and Teyana Taylor.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

item.title: Two Ohio Nursing Programs Show What Could Happen as US Limits Student Borrowing
item.description: Two different nursing school programs in Ohio offer a glimpse into what may happen when federal student borrowing has limits.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber and Andrea Fuller

item.title: America Turns 250: A Guide to the Coming Festivities
item.description: Girl Scouts singing folk songs, a flag-waving party and a Times Square ball drop are among the planned Semiquincentennial celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Help! Our Rental Car Got in an Accident, and We Can’t Get Our Security Deposit Back.
item.description: Thrifty held on to a couple’s full deposit for over a year after an accident in Australia, refusing to provide the invoice they needed for an insurance claim.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel

item.title: Malfunction Forces Japan to Take Restarted Nuclear Plant Offline
item.description: The setback occurred hours after one of the world’s largest nuclear complexes restarted, ending more than a decade of dormancy following the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi meltdown.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant seen from a residential neighborhood in Niigata Prefecture this month.

item.title: He Wants New Yorkers to Have a Stake in the Knicks and the Rangers
item.description: Adem Bunkeddeko, a state comptroller candidate, wants to use some of New York’s $290 billion pension fund to buy a percentage of Madison Square Garden Sports.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.category: New York State Common Retirement Fund
item.media:description: Adem Bunkeddeko believes that Madison Square Garden Sports is undervalued, pointing out that the company’s market capitalization is roughly half of the value of the New York Knicks and New York Rangers.

item.title: China Wins as Trump Cedes Leadership of the Global Economy
item.description: The president used a keynote speech at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland to renounce the last vestiges of the liberal democratic order.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: “Everybody took advantage of the United States,” President Trump told an audience at the World Economic Forum on Wednesday.

item.title: Supreme Court Hearing Reveals Unease Over Threats to Fed Independence
item.description: As the justices weighed the consequences of allowing President Trump to fire a Federal Reserve official, the president reprised his pressure campaign on the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lisa D. Cook, a Federal Reserve governor whom President Trump tried to fire last year over allegations of mortgage fraud.

item.title: FCC Targets Colbert and Kimmel in New Crackdown on Late-Night TV
item.description: The F.C.C. said it planned to enforce long-dormant rules on appearances by political candidates on network talk shows.
item.dc:creator: Jim Rutenberg
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brendan Carr, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

item.title: Judge Blocks Government From Reviewing Seized Washington Post Devices
item.description: The Post, in its first legal filing since the government searched the home of a reporter last week, had demanded the return of the seized materials.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:description: “The seizure chills speech, cripples reporting, and inflicts irreparable harm every day the government keeps its hands on protected materials,” The Washington Post argued in a legal filing.

item.title: 4 Takeaways from Supreme Court Hearing on Trump’s Firing of Lisa Cook
item.description: The justices were alert to the central bank’s crucial role and wary of issuing a broad ruling based on rushed briefing and incomplete information.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Colby Smith
item.media:description: Lisa Cook, a federal reserve governor, with her attorney Abbe Lowell, outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

item.title: Job Applicants Sue A.I. Recruitment Tool Company
item.description: A recently filed lawsuit claims the ratings assigned by A.I. screening software are similar to those of a credit agency and should be subject to the same laws.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Erin Kistler at her Los Angeles home.

item.title: Sports-Betting Scandals Are Ubiquitous. Whether Fans Will Care Is an Open Question.
item.description: Breaches of ethics in sports are almost as old as professional competitions. Here’s when they have affected the business — and when they haven’t.
item.dc:creator: Tania Ganguli
item.media:description: N.B.A. viewership was 60 percent higher compared with the year before on the night the F.B.I. held its news conference about a scandal involving figures from the Portland Trail Blazers.

item.title: Mediaite Starts a Newsletter to Summarize Media Newsletters
item.description: A new daily email from Mediaite intends to cut through the cacophony of online media news.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Mediaite’s founder, Dan Abrams.

item.title: Travel’s Latest Buzzword: ‘Microvacations’
item.description: Travelers short on vacation time are embarking on one- to three-day trips that take advantage of time zones and credit card points.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy

item.title: What Do Young Travelers Want? Exclusive Experiences.
item.description: More millennials and Gen Z-ers are planning trips around experiences, and the industry is responding with concerts, dinners and V.I.P. events.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

item.title: At Check-In, Your Face Is Increasingly Your ID
item.description: Facial recognition at security and immigration checkpoints and gates could ease airport hassles, even as the technology raises privacy concerns.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

item.title: Getting Travel Rewards Is Getting Easier
item.description: Program updates and new navigation tools help travelers negotiate the increasingly complicated universe of points.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: For Travelers in 2026, Prices Are All Over the Map
item.description: Luxury travelers can expect to pay more than they did last year, while budget travelers might get a break.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: ‘Adaptive Normalcy’ as the Trump Show Arrives at Davos
item.description: The president’s address at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland has trading partners and business executives on edge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Jordyn Holman, Lauren Hirsch and Ian Mount
item.media:description: President Trump is set to speak today at the World Economic Forum, an address that has generated excitement and some trepidation.

item.title: Stocks Rebound After Trump Backs Off European Tariffs
item.description: Stocks in the U.S. stabilized on Wednesday after an earlier slump had spilled into markets in Asia and Europe, ending a period of relative calm.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump takes questions from reporters during a news conference in the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: An Anxious Japan Restarts the World’s Biggest Nuclear Plant
item.description: Japan is reviving nuclear power, balancing the need for more clean energy against the lingering trauma of the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi disaster.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Reject Trump’s Attempt to Immediately Fire a Fed Governor
item.description: During arguments, key justices appeared concerned that the president’s efforts to oust Lisa Cook could imperil the central bank’s independence.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:description: The Supreme Court is expected to rule on Lisa Cook’s case in the coming weeks or months.

item.title: Uber Faces Growing Pressure Over Sexual Assault Record
item.description: From the ballot box in California to the halls of Congress and Wall Street, several new initiatives would require more oversight of how the company protects its passengers.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Tag Christof for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Century City, Los Angeles.

item.title: David Rosen, 95, Dies; Video Game Visionary and Co-Founder of Sega
item.description: He transformed his Japanese photo booth business into a gaming industry giant that created Mortal Kombat, Sonic the Hedgehog and more.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Trump Threatens New Trade War as Court Weighs Whether to Check Him
item.description: President Trump may be on the verge of having his authority on imposing tariffs curtailed, but that hasn’t slowed down his threats.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president has issued belligerent tariff threats against European countries in recent days.

item.title: Bessent Attended a Supreme Court Argument. Now He’s Telling Powell Not To.
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said it was a mistake for Jerome Powell to attend arguments in a case on Fed independence. But Mr. Bessent attended a tariff case.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: “If you’re trying not to politicize the Fed, for the Fed chair to be sitting there trying to put his thumb on the scale is a real mistake,” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said.

item.title: A.I., Big Tech and Trump Shine Most Brightly at the Davos Spectacle
item.description: The World Economic Forum is now dominated by global technology companies whose interests shunt aside most others.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Stocks Post Biggest Drop in Months as Tensions Over Greenland Mount
item.description: The S&P 500 saw its biggest decline since October, and market jitters spread to Asia on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: The Trump Drama Hits Davos
item.description: Greenland, tariffs and wobbling markets are the talk of the town at the World Economic Forum ahead of the president’s arrival on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has been explaining President Trump’s agenda to an antsy gathering at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: Netflix Revamps Its Warner Bros. Bid, Seeking to Thwart Paramount
item.description: Netflix will pay all cash for the $83 billion deal to acquire major parts of Warner Bros. Discovery, instead of a mix of cash and stock.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Benjamin Mullin and Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Netflix’s move puts pressure on Paramount to further revise its own bid after Warner Bros. Discovery rejected its latest offer.

item.title: Trump’s First Year Could Have Lasting Economic Consequences
item.description: President Trump’s policies have so far done little to change the overall state of the American economy, but economists warn they will ultimately weaken the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Economists from across the ideological spectrum warn that President Trump is setting the country on a path that will, in the long run, leave the economy less dynamic in the decades ahead.

item.title: Filoplumes Are Nature’s Super Feather
item.description: Filoplumes may be tiny, but these hairlike feathers enable nonstop flights that span thousands of miles.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins and Bryan Anselm
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: At a Seattle Port Rocked by Tariffs, There Were 70 Jobs for 600 Workers
item.description: Dock workers are used to uncertainty, but nothing since the Great Recession of 2008 compares to what they have experienced this year.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Since August, the monthly drop in traffic has been in the double digits compared to 2024. There was no pre-Christmas rush.

item.title: Nome, Alaska Is Now Key to Trump’s Global Ambitions
item.description: Nome, population 3,700, is accessible only by plane outside a few months when boats can pass through. But it will be the home of the nation’s only deepwater Arctic port.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Ruth Fremson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Nome’s existing dock will be turned into the country’s first deepwater Arctic port.

item.title: Federal Reserve Inquiry Clouds Trump’s Supreme Court Bid to Oust Lisa Cook
item.description: The court is set to hear Ms. Cook’s case challenging her firing as the Justice Department investigates Jerome H. Powell, the central bank chair.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Trump’s Trade Negotiator Says Response to Court Loss Would Be Immediate
item.description: If the Supreme Court rules against its tariffs, the Trump administration would begin replacing them immediately, said Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Jamieson Greer, the United States Trade Representative, on Air Force One in October.
